title: 109_hr1587
content: SECTION 1. MATCHING WILLING UNITED STATES WORKERS WITH EMPLOYERS. In an amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act, a new provision (v)(1) states that no alien can be admitted as a nonimmigrant under a specific section unless the employer has filed an attestation with the Secretary of Homeland Security and the Secretary of Labor. This attestation must confirm that the employer advertised the position on a designated internet-based job database. State employment security agencies require employers to post job openings on 'America's Job Bank' for 14 days. Employers must provide documentation of job postings and received resumes. The Secretary of Labor will verify this information with procedures established in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security. Employers submitting false documentation will face penalties, including ineligibility to file petitions for nonimmigrant workers for 3 to 10 years. The amendment made by subsection (a) will take effect 180 days after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 2. Matching nonimmigrant workers with employers. Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to limit the number of aliens issued visas under a specific category. Effective date is the first day of the fiscal year after enactment. Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to require aliens seeking nonimmigrant status to execute an affidavit stating their understanding of the terms. Aliens seeking nonimmigrant status must sign an affidavit confirming their understanding of the terms, including the prohibition on bringing family members and the requirement to leave the US before their authorized stay expires. They also agree to comply with entry and exit data system requirements and appear before an immigration inspector before departure. Aliens seeking nonimmigrant status must sign an affidavit affirming their understanding of the terms, including the requirement to depart the US before their authorized stay expires. The Secretary of Homeland Security shall designate inspectors to record the departure of nonimmigrants at ports where exit procedures are not implemented. Failure to depart as described will result in permanent ineligibility for any visa. SEC. 4. MANDATORY PARTICIPATION IN BASIC PILOT PROGRAM. Section 402(e) of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 is amended to require employers of H-2B nonimmigrants to participate in the basic pilot program starting January 1, 2006. Failure to comply will result in permanent revocation by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The Secretary of Homeland Security can permanently revoke an employer's authority to employ certain aliens under section 101(a)(15)(H)(ii)(b). SEC. 5. OFFSETS FOR THE INCREASE IN H-2B CAP. Elimination of Diversity Immigrant Program by amending sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act to remove diversity immigrant visas allocation. Amendments are made to the Immigration and Nationality Act, including redesignating paragraphs and adjusting subsections. The "Other Workers" classification is eliminated by reducing the worldwide level of employment-based immigrants. Amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act include increasing preference allocation for employment-based immigrants. This involves adjusting percentages in various paragraphs, such as increasing from 28.6 to 30.8 in paragraphs 1 and 2, and from 7.1 to 7.65 in paragraph 4. The "Other Workers" classification is eliminated by reducing the worldwide level of employment-based immigrants. Amendments to the Nicaraguan Adjustment and Central American Relief Act include temporary reductions in visas for brothers and sisters of citizens by reducing visas by 10,000. Subsection (e) is eliminated and subsection (f) is redesignated as subsection (e). The amendments to the Nicaraguan Adjustment and Central American Relief Act include reducing visas for siblings of citizens by 10,000. Subsection (f) is redesignated as subsection (e) with an effective date set for the first day of the fiscal year following the enactment of the Act.
